conclusion: The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
When the light source moves forward, it will be closer to the objects but still above them.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will move closer to the objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift towards their respective objects.
The size of the shadow depends on the distance between the object and the light source.
When the light source moves forward, the distance between the light source and the objects decreases.
This decrease in distance will result in larger shadows.
Shadow A will move closer to Object A and become larger.
Shadow B will move closer to Object B and increase its size.
Shadow C will move closer to Object C and become larger.
Shadow D will move closer to Object D and increase its size.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become larger as the light source moves forward.
